content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <catalog-item>    <common-information>       <cat-id>3416</cat-id>       <cat-type-code>PRJ</cat-type-code>       <metadata-workflow-state>Published / External</metadata-workflow-state>       <is-do-not-publish>N</is-do-not-publish>       <name>Highly Migratory Species Fishing Permits</name>       <title>Highly Migratory Species Fishing Permits</title>       <abstract>The Highly Migratory Species Management (HMS) Division issues a variety of fishing permits that allow commercial and recreational fishing using many different gear types and fishing practices.  The HMS Division issues permits to dealers for swordfish, tunas, and shark.  The HMS Division also authorizes scientific study and aquarium collection through an exempted fishing permit program.  The HMS Division also requires any fishing tournaments that target highly migratory species to register and report the catch if selected. </abstract>       <purpose>Permit and registration data are used to draft annual SAFE (Stock Assessment and Fishery Evaluation) Reports, stock assessments, and bluefin tuna and swordfish annual specifications.  Highly migratory species (HMS) tournament data are used to help meet ICCAT landings reporting requirements by facilitating selection of tournaments for reporting of fishing effort and landings by the South East Fishery Science Center.  These data are also used to quantify the tournaments held for HMS to improve fishery management measure development and by the public to determine applicable regulations for vessels participating in tournaments.  The data are used to help meet Amendment 2 to the Consolidated HMS Fishery Management Plan (FMP) requirements of the shark research fishery program by selecting participants for collection of shark species data used for stock assessments and to meet the research needs of NMFS.  Vessel permit data provide the universe of vessels participating in open access Atlantic HMS fisheries.</purpose>       <notes/>       <supplemental-info/>       <title>Highly Migratory Species Division Shark Research Fishery Permits</title>          <abstract>All commercial fishermen must submit an application and vessel/permit documentation to participate in the Atlantic shark research fishery, a program with 100% observer coverage to collect data on large coastal sharks (LCS), including sandbar sharks (a species prohibited from being landed and sold) for stock assessments.</abstract>       </item>       <item cat-id="22030" cat-type="DS" relation-type="HI">          <title>Highly Migratory Species Exempted Fishing Permits & Landings Data</title>          <abstract> Throughout the year the Highly Migratory Species (HMS) Management Division issues permits to researchers and many aquariums and private collectors.  The majority of these permits require reporting their catch history for each year.  Both permit information and catch data is entered into an MS Access database designed for the program.</abstract>       </item>       <item cat-id="22029" cat-type="DS" relation-type="HI">          <title>Highly Migratory Species Open Access Vessel Permits</title>          <abstract>This database identifies the universe of (permitted) vessels participating in open access commercial and recreational Atlantic highly migratory species (HMS) fisheries, including fisheries for bluefin tuna, swordfish, billfish, sharks, and BAYS (bigeye, albacore, yellowfin, and skipjack) tunas.  Open access commercial vessel permits include permits to fish for BAYS and bluefin tuna and swordfish, and include charter/headboat permits.  The data elements collected include identifying owner information, vessel description, vessel permit number, and home port.</abstract>       </item>       <item cat-id="22031" cat-type="DS" relation-type="HI">          <title>Highly Migratory Species Tournament Registration</title>          <abstract>All Atlantic recreational fishing tournaments that award points or prizes for the catch & release or landing of billfish, swordfish, sharks, or tunas are required to register with NOAA Fisheries at least 4 weeks prior to the start of the tournament.  To register, the tournament operator/director must complete an Atlantic Highly Migratory Species (HMS) tournament registration form (OMB 0642-0323) and submit it to the HMS Management Division.  The form includes tournament name, date(s), location, and HMS for which points or prizes will be awarded, as well as the tournament operator's name, mailing address, phone number, fax number, and e-mail address.  The form also gives the operator the option of ordering a specified number of Atlantic HMS recreational regulation booklets and other outreach materials for distribution at the tournament.  All of the information is entered into the HMS tournament registration database, which produces a unique confirmation number that is provided to the tournament operator by the HMS Management Division for proof of registration.</abstract>       </item>    </related-items>    <fgdc-contacts>       <fgdc-contact role="Metadata contact">          <contact-type>cntper</contact-type>
